title: 105_s1999
content:
The "Marriage Tax Penalty Elimination Act of 1998" aims to eliminate the marriage penalty in individual income tax rates by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments made by this Act will not be considered as changes in tax rates for tax purposes. The "Marriage Tax Penalty Elimination Act of 1998" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to eliminate the marriage penalty in individual income tax rates by imposing taxes on married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses. The tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $50,700: 15% of taxable income
- Over $50,700 but not over $122,800: $7,605, plus 28% of the excess over $50,700
- Over $122,800 but not over $256,200: $27,793, plus 31% of the excess over $122,800
- Over $256,200 but not over $556,900: $69,147, plus 36% of the excess over $256,200
- Over $556,900: $177,399, plus 39.6% of the excess over $556,900. The taxable income of every head of a household is subject to a tax based on a specific table. The tax rates based on taxable income for individuals are as follows:
- Not over $33,950: 15% of taxable income
- Over $33,950 but not over $87,700: $5,092.50 plus 28% of the excess over $33,950
- Over $87,700 but not over $142,000: $20,142.50 plus 31% of the excess over $87,700
- Over $142,000 but not over $278,450: $36,975.50 plus 36% of the excess over $142,000
- Over $278,450: $86,097.50 plus 39.6% of the excess over $278,450. There is a tax imposed on the taxable income of individuals not covered by subsections (a) or (b) according to a specific table. The tax rates for taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $25,350: 15% of taxable income
- Over $25,350 but not over $61,400: $3,802.50 plus 28% of excess over $25,350
- Over $61,400 but not over $128,100: $13,896.50 plus 31% of excess over $61,400
- Over $128,100 but not over $278,450: $34,573.50 plus 36% of excess over $128,100
- Over $278,450: $88,699.50 plus 39.6% of excess over $278,450. There is a tax imposed on the taxable income of estates and trusts according to a specific table. The tax rates for taxable income of estates and trusts are as follows:
- Not over $1,700: 15% of taxable income
- Over $1,700 but not over $4,000: $255 plus 28% of the excess over $1,700
- Over $4,000 but not over $6,100: $899 plus 31% of the excess over $4,000
- Over $6,100 but not over $8,350: $1,550 plus 36% of the excess over $6,100
- Over $8,350: $2,360 plus 39.6% of the excess over $8,350. Inflation adjustments apply for determining rates for 1999. Subsection (f) of section 1 is amended by changing dates in various paragraphs and removing paragraph (7). Conforming amendments are made to several provisions by updating the year from 1992 to 1997 in multiple sections. The text chunk provides amendments to various sections of the tax code, changing dates from 1992 to 1997 in multiple provisions. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, changing dates from 1992 to 1997 in multiple provisions. Amendments to various sections of the tax code change dates from 1992 to 1997 in multiple provisions, with effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998. Elimination of marriage penalty in standard deduction. The standard deduction amounts are adjusted as follows: $8,500 for joint returns or surviving spouses, $6,250 for heads of household, and $4,250 for all other cases. Adjustments for inflation will increase these amounts for taxable years after 1998. The standard deduction amounts for taxable years after 1998 are adjusted as follows: $8,500 for joint returns or surviving spouses, $6,250 for heads of household, and $4,250 for all other cases. Amendments made to subsections include increasing the amounts from $500 to $700, $600 to $850, and $750 to $1,050. Effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998.
